Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI's request funding for an ocean observation Research Coordination Network (RCN:OceanObsNetwork). The goal of the RCN is to foster a broad, multi-disciplinary dialogue, enabling more effective use of ocean observatories and observing systems consistent with national and international efforts. The major RCN activities are: increasing observing systems sustainability; stimulating inter-disciplinary cooperation; facilitating open data exchange; promoting interoperability; improving the flow of information to key stakeholders; and expanding effective capacity building. The proposed RCN will be the seed for a long-term, sustainable international forum on observatories for scientists and users of ocean information.

Broader Impacts:

This effort will encourage new partnerships, provide for new and innovative research outcomes and provide younger scientists with opportunities to lead technical task teams under senior Network mentors and facilitate both technical and leadership capacity building in under-represented groups. An emphasis on interoperability and exchange of data will both allow closer cooperation between observatories and also support improved global modeling. Interfacing with end users of information, whether in the government, academia or industry, will increase use of data, providing more visible impacts of observatories and ocean observing systems. Observatories are major investments and broadening the user community will help long-term sustainability of the systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Whether you live on the East Coast and worry about hurricanes, depend on rain for Midwest farming and are concerned about drought cycles or engaged in fishing and boating on the west coast, knowledge of the oceans and their impacts is a priority. The oceans provide many important functions within the Earth system including strong coupling with weather and climate dynamics, supplying food and energy resources, supporting commerce, offering extensive stabilization for variations in our environment and being a resource for biodiversity. The need for improved coordination in ocean observations continues to be urgent given climate considerations, and increasing need for sustainable food sources and energy. Ocean researchers must work across disciplines to provide policy makers with clear and understandable assessments of the state of the ocean.

The dynamics of the ocean on a global scale are not understood very well. The potential for major changes in ocean currents, in the atmospheric-ocean surface interactions and the evolution of ocean fish and other populations are only some of the obvious issues. Hidden risks may turn out to be the major challenges for humanity. Yet ocean observations are many times fragmented, focused primarily on national and regional needs while a coordinated global information network is needed as well.

From the above, it is not surprising that one of the five grand challenges for science is “developing the observation systems needed to manage global and regional environmental change.” Ocean observation is both important and challenging. At a high level, the goal of the RCN was to foster a broad, multi-disciplinary dialogue, enabling more effective use of ocean observing systems. This dialogue engaged national and international efforts. It is an important part of science, now and more so in the future.. To achieve this goal, the RCN defined a series of objectives:

  • Motivate commitments to sustaining ocean and marine observing systems
  • Stimulate inter-disciplinary cooperation for both observations and analyses
    • Facilitate open exchange of ocean data
    •  Promote interoperability
    • Improve the flow of critical ocean observation information to key stakeholders

 

The RCN organized three events during the reporting period of November 2016 to November 2017 to engage a community vision for sustainability and increased effectiveness of ocean observations.

The first event was the annual RCN meeting in December 2016 (figure 1) that focused on recent developments to support policy decisions bringing information “from sensors to users”. Underlying this are the advancements of technologies such as eDNA, new small, low power sensors as well as autonomous inter-connected platforms.

Figure 1: Participants of the RCN annual meeting 2016

The second event was the Implementation of Multi-disciplinary Sustained Ocean Observation (IMSOO) Workshop held in February 2017 that successfully addressed three main objectives:

•           To build on the established societal and scientific requirements expressed in Essential Ocean Variables and identify the key applications and phenomena that will benefit from co-located, multi-disciplinary sustained observations;

•           To identify near-term innovation priorities for observing platforms and sensors to enable multi-disciplinary observations; and

•           To identify programmatic and professional connections between existing and emerging observing networks and modeling efforts that will increase multi-disciplinary observations and analyses.

The third event was a workshop on “Evolving and Sustaining Ocean Best Practices,” which was organized in response to a growing need for global and sustainable ocean best practice management. The Workshop provided an opportunity for leaders of the global ocean observing community to guide the creation of a new process for best practice management. The outcomes of the workshop included a review of a prototype repository of best practices, discussions on the critical needs of the ocean observing community and a consensus on the definition of best practices and the most effective means for their use.

The above work continued in 2018 with two additional workshops. A follow-up to the IMSOO workshop, entitled “Implementation of global, sustained and multidisciplinary observations of plankton communities” was held in June 2018.  The workshop was motivated by the recognition that a global ocean observing system is urgently needed to monitor marine biodiversity and ecosystems to ensure conservation and sustainable development. Monitoring is required as resource availability and ecosystem management are changing in ways that we cannot yet predict, due to growing resource use and simultaneous marked global environmental change. In addition, a second best practices workshop was held to define a future vision. For this, the global ocean observing system will need to support UN Agenda 2030 (including the Sustainable Development Goals), the Decade of Ocean Science in support of Sustainable Development, and other international environmental agreements and initiatives. 

This work  was sponsored through NSF Grant OCE-1143683
